0.title: Guiding Questions
0.content: . | What is data? | What is this course | .

1.title: Pre-work
1.content: . | Big? Smart? Clean? Messy? Data in the Humanities | Humanities Data: A Necessary Contradiction | .

2.title: The Plan
2.content: . | We Data: An Icebreaking Activity | Discussion | Review syllabus | Slides linked here | .

3.title: We Data: An Icebreaking Activity
3.content: I want to get to know you. In the spirit of the course, your job is to make a dataset about yourselves to share back with me. You have 45 minutes in which to do so. You have to hit the following buckets. | Identify your data . | Who are you? | . | Describe your data . | What are you interested in describing as a part of your dataset? What are you not? | . | Collect . | Gather your data in one place. | . | Clean . | Edit the dataset so that it’s in a presentable, consistent format. | . | Analyze . | What stories are in your dataset? | . | Distribute . | How will you share it back to me? | . | . Some advice . | Not everyone has to work on the same things! Divide up. | Use what you have. | Don’t spend so much time talking. Do. | .

4.title: Homework
4.content: . | By Friday morning at 9:00 AM, share your class dataset with me along with a fifty-word reflection on the activity. What was the most challenging piece? What did you learn? | .

6.title: Plan
6.content: . | Work time for identification of your shared data project and to develop a plan for how the work will go. | .

7.title: Homework
7.content: . | Send the topic and planned dataset to me by Friday at 9:00 AM. | .

9.title: Plan
9.content: . | Work time to finalize the description of your shared data project. Focus on metadata schema. | .

10.title: Homework
10.content: . | Send the full metadata schema and breakdown for the data you will be collecting for your project by Friday at 9:00AM. Describe in 50 words what sorts of decisions were necessary to come to in deciding on this schema. What stories will or will not be told? | .

12.title: Plan
12.content: . | Work time to plan for and then collect the data for your project using webscraper.io. | .

13.title: Homework
13.content: . | Send the dataset along to me by Friday at 9:00AM. | .

15.title: Plan
15.content: . | Work time to begin cleaning your project with Google Open Refine. | .

16.title: Homework
16.content: . | Send the cleaned dataset along to me by Friday at 9:00AM. | .

18.title: Plan
18.content: . | Work time to for analysis of your dataset. | .

19.title: Homework
19.content: . | Send provisional analyses of your dataset along to me by Friday at 9:00AM. | .

21.title: Plan
21.content: . | Work time to develop and implement the distribution plan for your dataset. | .

22.title: Homework
22.content: . | Distribute your dataset and documentation by Friday at 9:00AM. | .

27.title: Guiding Questions
27.content: . | What counts? | Where can you find it? | How do you tell what is missing? | .

28.title: Pre-work
28.content: . | Wikipedia Definition of Data | Explore . | US Government’s Open Data | Google Datasets | Awesome Public Datasets | . | On Missing Data Sets | .

29.title: Plan
29.content: . | Introduction: “Data: A Definition” | Workshop: Is it Data? What don’t you see? . | What counts? | What don’t you see? | . | Slides linked here | .

30.title: Homework
30.content: . | Brainstorm a list of three datasets that don’t seem to exist that you might be interested in. Give each one a 2-3 sentence description. Send your list to me by Friday at 9:00 AM. | .

32.title: Guiding Questions
32.content: . | How do we describe data? | What are metadata standards? | .

33.title: Pre-work
33.content: . | Describing Data LibGuide | What are Metadata Standards? | .

34.title: Plan
34.content: . | Introduction: Formats and Standards | Activity: Organizing and Describing | Slides linked here | .

35.title: Homework
35.content: . | Select a cultural interest (film, books, music) of yours and create a dataset from it. You should have at least 10 objects in your dataset with five metadata categories each. Be detailed! Bonus points for using an established metadata standard. Submit Friday by 9:00 AM. | .

37.title: Guiding Questions
37.content: . | What are tools for gathering materials? | What are issues in the use of these tools? | .

38.title: Pre-work
38.content: . | Data Collection | Install and work through webscraper.io documentation | .

39.title: Plan
39.content: . | Introduction: On Gathering | Activity: Workshop on webscraper.io | Slides linked here | .

40.title: Homework
40.content: . | Practice scraping! Try using webscraper.io to scrape this simple countries of the world example. By Friday at 9:00 AM, send me a CSV of your results. | Identify three other sites that contain data you might be interested in collecting. Think especially about different kinds of content, especially those related to arts, culture, and the humanities. Share them by Friday at 9:00 AM. | .

42.title: Guiding Questions
42.content: . | What is the importance of clean, tidy data? | How do we fix problems with our data? | .

43.title: Pre-work
43.content: . | Open Refine Documentation; install and work through each piece of the documentation, stopping after you finish the section on reconciling. | Cleaning Data with Susan Walsh from the “Data Career Podcast” | .

44.title: Plan
44.content: . | Introduction: On Cleaning | Activity: Workshop on Google Open Refine | Slides linked here | .

45.title: Homework
45.content: . | Work through this lesson on The Programming Historian. Send a screenshot of your successful results along by Friday at 9:00 AM. | .

47.title: Guiding Questions
47.content: . | How does all the work we have done so far enable us to ask new questions of our materials? | How do quantitative and qualitative analyses relate to one another? | .

48.title: Pre-work
48.content: . | Qualitative vs Quantitative Research | Looker Studio Tutorial for Beginners. Try to follow on your own. | .

49.title: Plan
49.content: . | Introduction: Qualitative vs Quantitative Analysis | Activity: Workshop on Looker Studio | Slides linked here | .

50.title: Homework
50.content: . | Use looker studio to tell a story about the data. By 9:00 AM send me a paragraph describing what you see and a screenshot of any visualization that is meaningful to you. | .

52.title: Guiding Questions
52.content: . | How and why do you share your work? | How do you do so in a form that is usable for others? | .

53.title: Pre-work
53.content: . | Explore Post45 Data Collective | Explore Responsible Datasets in Context | .

54.title: Plan
54.content: . | Introduction: Publishing your Work | Activity: Return to Icebreaker Dataset | Slides linked here | .

55.title: Homework
55.content: . | Come up with three potential data sources to collect and hone into a final project. Email to me by 9:00 AM Friday. For each of them, share a link and a short description of it. | Meet as a group to discuss your potential project ideas. As a group, you will pitch three potential ideas to a group of judges next time. | . And as a preview, your final outcome will entail the following, so you might want to touch on some pieces of this during your presentations. | Collected, cleaned dataset | Metadata breakdown | Narrative of the dataset | Usage examples | Basic analysis | Credits | Distributed to a repository (potentially!) | .

57.title: Guiding Questions
57.content: . | What will you work on for the remainder of the course? | .

58.title: Pre-work
58.content: . | Come prepared to present three potential final data sources for your final project. You’ll be sharing them for a panel of judges to discuss as a group. | Answer these questions in your presentations: . | What is the dataset? Why do we care? | How viable does it seem to collect the data? to clean it? | What questions might someone answer with the dataset that can’t otherwise be answered? | Are there any concerns about doing this work on this data, ethical or legal? | What are the pro’s and cons of each data source? | Which stories are you most interested in? | . | .

59.title: Plan
59.content: . | Students will pitch three potential ideas as a group to a panel of judges. Ten minutes max on each idea. | .

60.title: Homework
60.content: . | Submit a short write-up of your ideas by Friday at 9:00AM. One single-spaced page max, so roughly one paragraph for each idea. | .
